Conjugacy Classes of Permutations

"Conjugacy" might just be the only word with enough power to traumatize a mathematician, a linguist, and a divorce lawyer all at once.

Conjugate permutations

We know that group elements which are conjugate to one another share many properties: as a previous page described, if ggg and kkk are conjugate to one another via k=hgh−1k = hgh^{-1}k=hgh−1, then kkk is nothing more than "performing ggg in the context of hhh". In particular, they share a common order; however, with permutations, they share something much stronger.

Lemma. If a cycle is conjugate to another cycle via some σ∈Sn\sigma \in S_nσ∈Sn​, then the two cycles are permutations of one another via σ\sigmaσ:

σ∈Sn, σ(a1a2...ak)σ−1=(σ(a1)σ(a2)...σ(ak)).\sigma \in S_n,\ \sigma(a_1 a_2 ... a_k)\sigma^{-1} = (\sigma(a_1)\sigma(a_2) ... \sigma(a_k)).σ∈Sn​, σ(a1​a2​...ak​)σ−1=(σ(a1​)σ(a2​)...σ(ak​)).

Proof.

(For the rest of this section, permutations in SnS_nSn​ act on the set X={1,2,...,n}X = \{1, 2, ..., n\}X={1,2,...,n}.)

The equality of the above two permutations hinges on whether they act the same way on each element x∈X={1,2,...,n}x \in X = \{1, 2, ..., n\}x∈X={1,2,...,n}. Consider the element σ(x)\sigma(x)σ(x) for every x∈Xx \in Xx∈X; σ\sigmaσ is an invertible and thus a bijective mapping from XXX to itself.

For the left-hand side, we have

σ(a1a2...ak)σ−1(σ(x))=σ(a1a2...ak)(x)\sigma(a_1 a_2 ... a_k)\sigma^{-1}(\sigma (x)) = \sigma(a_1 a_2 ... a_k)(x)σ(a1​a2​...ak​)σ−1(σ(x))=σ(a1​a2​...ak​)(x)

by associativity. If x=aix= a_ix=ai​ for i=1,...,ki = 1, ..., ki=1,...,k, we thus have

σ(ak+1)\sigma (a_{k+1})σ(ak+1​)

or, if i=ki = ki=k, then σ(a1)\sigma(a_1)σ(a1​). Alternatively, if xxx is not one of the aia_iai​s, then the output is simply xxx itself. Thus, the left-hand side permutation acts on XXX via

{σ(xi)→σ(xi+1), i=1,2,...,k−1σ(xk)→σ(x1), i=kσ(x)→σ(x),x∉{a1,...,ak}\begin{cases} \sigma(x_i) \to \sigma(x_{i+1}),\ i = 1, 2, ..., k-1\\ \sigma(x_k) \to \sigma(x_1),\ i = k \\ \sigma(x) \to \sigma(x), x \notin \{a_1, ..., a_k\} \end{cases}⎩⎨⎧​σ(xi​)→σ(xi+1​), i=1,2,...,k−1σ(xk​)→σ(x1​), i=kσ(x)→σ(x),x∈/{a1​,...,ak​}​

which precisely defines the cycle (σ(a1),σ(a2),...,σ(ak))(\sigma(a_1), \sigma(a_2), ..., \sigma(a_k))(σ(a1​),σ(a2​),...,σ(ak​)). (Considering how the permutations act on σ(X)\sigma(X)σ(X) is equivalent to considering how they act on the set XXX, as σ\sigmaσ is a bijection from XXX to XXX.)

The primary implication of this lemma is that

Corollary. Any two cycles of the same length are conjugate to one another.

Proof.

Let σ=(a1a2...ak)\sigma = (a_1 a_2 ... a_k)σ=(a1​a2​...ak​) and τ=(b1b2..bk)\tau = (b_1 b_2 .. b_k)τ=(b1​b2​..bk​) be two permutations in SnS_nSn​. Then the permutation defined by the product of transpositions

ρ=(a1b1)(a2b2)...(akbk)\rho = (a_1 b_1) (a_2 b_2) ... (a_k b_k)ρ=(a1​b1​)(a2​b2​)...(ak​bk​)

which, with the case ai=bia_i = b_iai​=bi​ being treated as a "do nothing" permutation, maps σ\sigmaσ onto τ\tauτ via τ=ρσρ−1\tau = \rho\sigma\rho^{-1}τ=ρσρ−1 by the above lemma.

This leads us to

Theorem. Two permutations are conjugate if and only if their disjoint cycle decompositions feature permutations of the same length: for instance, two permutations in S4S_4S4​ comprised of disjoint cycles of length 1,1,21, 1, 21,1,2 are conjugate.

Proof.

Let σ\sigmaσ and τ\tauτ be two permutations in SnS_nSn​, with σ\sigmaσ having disjoint cycle decomposition

σ=(a11a21...ak11)...(a1ma2m...akmm)\sigma = (a_1^1 a_2^1 ... a_{k_1}^1) ... (a_1^m a_2^m ... a_{k_m}^m)σ=(a11​a21​...ak1​1​)...(a1m​a2m​...akm​m​)

with cycles of lengths k1k_1k1​, k2k_2k2​, ..., kmk_mkm​. If σ\sigmaσ and τ\tauτ are conjugates via some permutation ρ∈Sn\rho \in S_nρ∈Sn​, i.e. ρσρ−1=τ\rho \sigma \rho^{-1} = \tauρσρ−1=τ, then we have

ρσρ−1=ρ(a11a21...ak11)...(a1ma2m...akmm)ρ−1=(ρ(a11a21...ak11)ρ−1)...(ρ(a1ma2m...akmm)ρ−1)=(ρ(a11)ρ(a21)...ρ(ak1)1)...(ρ(a1m)ρ(a2m)...ρ(akm)m)=τ\begin{aligned} \rho \sigma \rho^{-1} &= \rho (a_1^1 a_2^1 ... a_{k_1}^1) ... (a_1^m a_2^m ... a_{k_m}^m) \rho^{-1} \\ &= (\rho (a_1^1 a_2^1 ... a_{k_1}^1) \rho^{-1}) ... (\rho(a_1^m a_2^m ... a_{k_m}^m)\rho^{-1}) \\ &= (\rho(a_1^1) \rho(a_2^1) ... \rho(a_{k_1})^1)...(\rho(a_1^m) \rho(a_2^m) ... \rho(a_{k_m})^m) = \tau \end{aligned}ρσρ−1​=ρ(a11​a21​...ak1​1​)...(a1m​a2m​...akm​m​)ρ−1=(ρ(a11​a21​...ak1​1​)ρ−1)...(ρ(a1m​a2m​...akm​m​)ρ−1)=(ρ(a11​)ρ(a21​)...ρ(ak1​​)1)...(ρ(a1m​)ρ(a2m​)...ρ(akm​​)m)=τ​

by the above lemma. The cycles of a disjoint cycle decomposition must contain all of XXX, i.e. a11,...,ak11,a21,...,a1m,...,akmma_1^1, ..., a^1_{k_1}, a_2^1, ..., a^m_1, ..., a_{k_m}^ma11​,...,ak1​1​,a21​,...,a1m​,...,akm​m​ are exactly the elements of XXX; and as any permutation ρ\rhoρ is a bijective mapping from XXX to XXX, the set given by

ρ(a11),...,ρ(ak11),...,ρ(a1m),...,ρ(akmm)\rho(a_1^1), ..., \rho(a_{k_1}^1),..., \rho(a_1^m), ..., \rho(a_{k_m}^m)ρ(a11​),...,ρ(ak1​1​),...,ρ(a1m​),...,ρ(akm​m​)

are also exactly the elements of XXX. Therefore, ρσρ−1\rho \sigma \rho^{-1}ρσρ−1 in the form expressed above is a disjoint cycle decomposition; and as disjoint cycle decompositions are unique, and given that ρσρ−1=τ\rho \sigma \rho^{-1} =\tauρσρ−1=τ, the above must also be the unique disjoint cycle decomposition of τ\tauτ. Thus, σ\sigmaσ and τ\tauτ have disjoint cycle decompositions involving cycles of equal lengths.

Conversely, suppose that σ,τ∈Sn\sigma, \tau \in S_nσ,τ∈Sn​ are two permutations with disjoint cycle decompositions involving cycles of equal lengths:

σ=(a11a21...ak11)...(a1ma2m...akmm)\sigma = (a_1^1 a_2^1 ... a_{k_1}^1) ... (a_1^m a_2^m ... a_{k_m}^m)σ=(a11​a21​...ak1​1​)...(a1m​a2m​...akm​m​)

and

τ=(b11b21...bk11)...(b1mb2m...bkmm).\tau = (b_1^1 b_2^1 ... b_{k_1}^1) ... (b_1^m b_2^m ... b_{k_m}^m).τ=(b11​b21​...bk1​1​)...(b1m​b2m​...bkm​m​).

Define the permutation

ρ(aji)=bji\rho(a^i_{j}) = b^i_jρ(aji​)=bji​

which satisfies the properties of a permutation because the ajia^i_jaji​s and the bjib^i_jbji​s are both the set XXX, and no two ajia^i_jaji​s nor any two bjib^i_jbji​s are equal by the Disjoint Cycle Decomposition theorem. Thus ρ\rhoρ is a bijection from XXX to XXX, and is a permutation in SnS_nSn​. By this construction we directly obtain

ρσρ−1=τ\rho \sigma \rho^{-1} = \tauρσρ−1=τ

through the above lemma, proving the statement. □\square□

Cycle types and conjugacy classes

Definition. From the above statements, we know that two permutations with disjoint cycle decompositions whose cycles are of equal lengths are conjugate; call the number of 111-cycles, 222-cycles, ..., nnn-cycles in the disjoint cycle decomposition of a permutation σ∈Sn\sigma \in S_nσ∈Sn​, denoted σ1\sigma_1σ1​, σ2\sigma_2σ2​, ..., σn\sigma_nσn​ respectively, the cycle type of σ\sigmaσ. This is usually written 1σ12σ2...nσn1^{\sigma_1} 2^{\sigma_2}...n^{\sigma_n}1σ1​2σ2​...nσn​.

By construction, two permutations with the same cycle type are conjugate; in other words, they belong to the same conjugacy class (i.e. the same orbit under the conjugation action). Moreover, we also have the following:

Definition. Recall that the centralizer of an element ggg in a group GGG as its stabilizer under the conjugation action:

CG(g)={h∈G:hgh−1=g}C_G(g) = \{h \in G: hgh^{-1} = g\}CG​(g)={h∈G:hgh−1=g}

or, alternatively, as all the elements in GGG that commute with ggg.

Lemma. Suppose that a permutation σ∈Sn\sigma \in S_nσ∈Sn​ has cycle type 1σ12σ2...nσn1^{\sigma_1} 2^{\sigma_2}...n^{\sigma_n}1σ1​2σ2​...nσn​. Then the order of the centralizer of σ\sigmaσ is

∣CSn(σ)∣=1σ1(σ1!)2σ2(σ2!)...nσn(σn!).|C_{S_n}(\sigma)| = 1^{\sigma_1}(\sigma_1!)2^{\sigma_2}(\sigma_2!) ... n^{\sigma_n}(\sigma_n!).∣CSn​​(σ)∣=1σ1​(σ1​!)2σ2​(σ2​!)...nσn​(σn​!).

Proof.

The centralizer of σ\sigmaσ is all permutations τ∈Sn\tau \in S_nτ∈Sn​ such that τστ−1=σ\tau \sigma \tau^{-1} = \sigmaτστ−1=σ. Suppose that σ\sigmaσ has disjoint cycle decomposition

σ=(a11a21...ak11)...(a1ma2m...akmm)\sigma = (a_1^1 a_2^1 ... a_{k_1}^1) ... (a_1^m a_2^m ... a_{k_m}^m)σ=(a11​a21​...ak1​1​)...(a1m​a2m​...akm​m​)

leading to

τστ−1=(τ(a11)τ(a21)...τ(ak11))...(τ(a1m)τ(a2m)...τ(akmm)).\tau \sigma \tau^{-1} = (\tau(a_1^1) \tau(a_2^1) ... \tau(a_{k_1}^1)) ... (\tau(a_1^m) \tau(a_2^m) ... \tau(a_{k_m}^m)).τστ−1=(τ(a11​)τ(a21​)...τ(ak1​1​))...(τ(a1m​)τ(a2m​)...τ(akm​m​)).

Cycles remain the same if a permutation acts on them in two ways: 1) if the permutation cycles them, i.e.

(τ(a1)τ(a2)...τ(ak))(\tau(a_1)\tau(a_2) ... \tau(a_k))(τ(a1​)τ(a2​)...τ(ak​))

is a cycle of (a1a2...ak)(a_1 a_2 ... a_k)(a1​a2​...ak​), or 2) if the permutation swaps them with another cycle of the same length, e.g. a 333-cycle with another 333-cycle. For a kkk-cycle (k=1,2,...,nk = 1, 2, ..., nk=1,2,...,n), there are σk!\sigma_k!σk​! ways to permute the σk\sigma_kσk​ cycles in the disjoint cycle decomposition of σ\sigmaσ; for each of these ways, there are kσkk^{\sigma_k}kσk​ ways to cycle all σk\sigma_kσk​ of these cycles. Thus, we obtain

∣CSn(σ)∣=1σ1(σ1!)2σ2(σ2!)...nσn(σn!)|C_{S_n}(\sigma)| = 1^{\sigma_1}(\sigma_1!)2^{\sigma_2}(\sigma_2!) ... n^{\sigma_n}(\sigma_n!)∣CSn​​(σ)∣=1σ1​(σ1​!)2σ2​(σ2​!)...nσn​(σn​!)

in total.

Corollary. Let σ∈Sn\sigma \in S_nσ∈Sn​ have cycle type 1σ12σ2...nσn1^{\sigma_1} 2^{\sigma_2}...n^{\sigma_n}1σ1​2σ2​...nσn​. Then the size of the conjugacy class of σ\sigmaσ, denoted ∣ccl(σ)∣|\text{ccl}(\sigma)|∣ccl(σ)∣, is

∣ccl(σ)∣=n!1σ1(σ1!)2σ2(σ2!)...nσn(σn!).|\text{ccl}(\sigma)| = \frac{n!}{1^{\sigma_1}(\sigma_1!)2^{\sigma_2}(\sigma_2!) ... n^{\sigma_n}(\sigma_n!)}.∣ccl(σ)∣=1σ1​(σ1​!)2σ2​(σ2​!)...nσn​(σn​!)n!​.

Proof. SnS_nSn​ has order n!n!n!; an application of the Orbit-Stabilizer theorem on the orbit of σ\sigmaσ, which is ccl(σ)\text{ccl}(\sigma)ccl(σ), and the stabilizer of σ\sigmaσ, which is CSn(σ)C_{S_n}(\sigma)CSn​​(σ), yields the above expression.

We know that normal subgroups only arise from the unions of conjugacy classes; as such, knowing exactly what the conjugacy classes are (permutations of the same cycle type) and how big each conjugacy class is grants us valuable insight in searching for normal subgroups.

Example. Find the normal subgroups of S4S_4S4​.

The possible cycle types of a permutation σ∈S4\sigma \in S_4σ∈S4​ are 142030401^42^0 3^0 4^014203040 (the identity permutation); 122130401^2 2^1 3^0 4^012213040 (a single transposition); 112031401^1 2^0 3^1 4^011203140 (a 333-cycle); 102230401^0 2^2 3^0 4^010223040 (two transpositions); and 102030411^0 2^0 3^0 4^110203041 (a 444-cycle).

The identity permutation stands alone as a conjugate class; using the formula above, the sizes of the other four conjugacy classes are 666, 888, 333, and 666 respectively. By Lagrange's Theorem, subgroups are of order 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 12 and 24; any subgroup will contain the identity conjugacy class.

The union of the identity conjugacy class and the class of two transpositions is size 444, which is C2×C2C_2\times C_2C2​×C2​ and a normal subgroup.

If a normal subgroup contains the conjugacy class of single transpositions, then it must be S4S_4S4​ itself as any symmetric group is generated out of single transpositions.

If a normal subgroup contains the conjugacy class of 333-cycles - which, when combined with the identity conjugacy class, yields a set of size 999, and must then be either a subgroup of size 121212 or 242424 by Lagrange's Theorem - then we would have (for size 121212)

1+8+3=121 + 8 + 3 = 121+8+3=12

through the union of the identity conjugacy class, the class of 333-cycles, and the class of two transpositions of size 333; this is A4A_4A4​. For size 242424, we simply have S4S_4S4​.

Finally, if a normal subgroup contains the conjugacy class of 444-cycles, then by

(1234)(1324)=(142)(1234)(1324) = (142)(1234)(1324)=(142)

we know that it must also contain at least one 333-cycle, and by the requirement that normal subgroups are unions of entire conjugacy classes, it must contain every single 333-cycle. This yields S4S_4S4​, as it would lead to a subgroup of size 1+6+8=151 + 6 + 8 = 151+6+8=15 which can only be S4S_4S4​ by Lagrange's Theorem.

Therefore, we yield the normal subgroups

({e},C2×C2,A4,S4)◃S4.(\{e\}, C_2\times C_2, A_4, S_4)\triangleleft S_4.({e},C2​×C2​,A4​,S4​)◃S4​.

Conjugacy classes in alternating groups

In SnS_nSn​, the conjugacy classes are formed simply by all permutations of a certain cycle type; in AnA_nAn​, things are muddied by the fact that odd permutations are no longer accessible to us for conjugation. For instance, any two 333-cycles are conjugate in S3S_3S3​ by virtue of having the same cycle type, e.g. (123)(123)(123) and (213)(213)(213); however, they are not conjugate in A3≅C3A_3 \cong C_3A3​≅C3​ because A3A_3A3​ is an abelian group, and elements in an abelian group are conjugate if and only if they are equal via

gag−1=gg−1a=a.gag^{-1} = gg^{-1}a = a.gag−1=gg−1a=a.

Closer inspection gives us the following result:

Theorem. Suppose that σ∈An\sigma \in A_nσ∈An​; denote the conjugacy classes of σ\sigmaσ in SnS_nSn​ and AnA_nAn​ by cclSn(σ)\text{ccl}_{S_n}(\sigma)cclSn​​(σ) and cclAn(σ)\text{ccl}_{A_n}(\sigma)cclAn​​(σ) respectively. Then cclAn(σ)\text{ccl}_{A_n}(\sigma)cclAn​​(σ) is either half the size or the same size as cclSn(σ)\text{ccl}_{S_n}(\sigma)cclSn​​(σ).

Proof

We have ∣Sn∣=2∣An∣|S_n| = 2|A_n|∣Sn​∣=2∣An​∣; by the Orbit-Stabilizer theorem, we have

{∣Sn∣=∣cclSn(σ)∣∣CSn(σ)∣∣An∣=∣cclAn(σ)∣∣CAn(σ)∣\begin{cases} |S_n| = |\text{ccl}_{S_n}(\sigma)||C_{S_n}(\sigma)| \\ |A_n| = |\text{ccl}_{A_n}(\sigma)||C_{A_n}(\sigma)| \end{cases}{∣Sn​∣=∣cclSn​​(σ)∣∣CSn​​(σ)∣∣An​∣=∣cclAn​​(σ)∣∣CAn​​(σ)∣​

and thus

∣cclSn(σ)∣∣CSn(σ)∣=2∣cclAn(σ)∣∣CAn(σ)∣.|\text{ccl}_{S_n}(\sigma)||C_{S_n}(\sigma)| = 2|\text{ccl}_{A_n}(\sigma)||C_{A_n}(\sigma)|.∣cclSn​​(σ)∣∣CSn​​(σ)∣=2∣cclAn​​(σ)∣∣CAn​​(σ)∣.

We know that ∣CAn(σ)∣|C_{A_n}(\sigma)|∣CAn​​(σ)∣ is also a factor of ∣CSn(σ)∣|C_{S_n}(\sigma)|∣CSn​​(σ)∣ (AnA_nAn​ is a subgroup of SnS_nSn​, and so CAnC_{A_n}CAn​​ is a subgroup of CSnC_{S_n}CSn​​); in fact, we know very precisely that CAnC_{A_n}CAn​​ is either half the size of CSnC_{S_n}CSn​​ or exactly the same size as CSnC_{S_n}CSn​​: every subgroup of SnS_nSn​ is either half even or completely even, i.e. either half in AnA_nAn​ or completely in AnA_nAn​, with the former resulting in

∣CAn∣=12∣CSn∣|C_{A_n}| = \frac{1}{2}|C_{S_n}|∣CAn​​∣=21​∣CSn​​∣

and the latter in

∣CAn∣=∣CSn∣.|C_{A_n}| = |C_{S_n}|.∣CAn​​∣=∣CSn​​∣.

Substituting this into the equation above results in

∣cclAn(σ)∣=2∣cclSn(σ)∣|\text{ccl}_{A_n}(\sigma)| = 2|\text{ccl}_{S_n}(\sigma)|∣cclAn​​(σ)∣=2∣cclSn​​(σ)∣

or

∣cclAn(σ)∣=∣cclSn(σ)∣|\text{ccl}_{A_n}(\sigma)| = |\text{ccl}_{S_n}(\sigma)|∣cclAn​​(σ)∣=∣cclSn​​(σ)∣

as desired. □\square□

Corollary. Call a conjugacy class cclSn(σ)\text{ccl}_{S_n}(\sigma)cclSn​​(σ) that is halved in size in AnA_nAn​ a split conjugacy class. If the stabilizer of σ\sigmaσ in SnS_nSn​ is completely even, the conjugacy class splits; otherwise, it does not split.

This is derived directly from the proof above.

Example. Describe the conjugacy classes of A4A_4A4​ and derive its normal subgroups.

To start with, let's describe the conjugacy classes of S4S_4S4​. From the above example, we have

Conjugacy classOrder of class
111-cycle, ${e}1
Single transpositions6
Double transpositions3
333-cycles8
444-cycles6

In which:

  • The identity conjugacy class is not split (as all its elements are also in A4A_4A4​)
  • The conjugacy class of single transpositions are odd, and are not in A4A_4A4​.
  • The conjugacy class of double transpositions lie in A4A_4A4​. Their centralizers contain an odd element (e.g. (12)(34)(12)(34)(12)(34) is stabilized by (12)(12)(12)), and as such we know they are half odd; thus, this conjugacy class is not split in A4A_4A4​.
  • The conjugacy class of 333-cycles lie in A4A_4A4​. The Orbit-Stabilizer theorem shows that the size of their centralizer is 24/8=324 / 8 = 324/8=3 (there are 888 333-cycles); as such, every element in this subgroup has order 333 and is therefore a 333-cycle (which is even). Thus the centralizer of this conjugacy class lies entirely in A4A_4A4​, and so this class is split into two classes of size 444.
  • The conjugacy class of 444-cycles are odd and do not lie in A4A_4A4​.

Thus, the conjugacy classes of A4A_4A4​ are:

  • The identity conjugacy class (not split, order 111)
  • The conjugacy class of double transpositions (not split, order 333)
  • The two conjugacy classes formed from 333-cycles (split, each of order 444)

By Lagrange's Theorem, the normal subgroups of A4A_4A4​ can be of order 111, 222, 333, 444, 666 or 121212; our conjugacy classes have orders 1,31, 31,3 and 444. Thus we either have

1=11 = 11=1

which is the identity normal subgroup {e}\{e\}{e};

1+3=41 + 3 = 41+3=4

i.e. the union of the identity subgroup and the double transposition conjugacy class. This is C2×C2C_2 \times C_2C2​×C2​, and forms a normal subgroup. Finally, any normal subgroup including a single split conjugacy class of 333-cycles (of order 444) must also include the identity; and so it has order

1+4=51+ 4= 51+4=5

But all other conjugacy classes in A4A_4A4​ are either of order 444 or order 333, which cannot add to 555 to result in 666; thus, the normal subgroup corresponding to this case must have order 121212 by Lagrange's Theorem, and will be A4A_4A4​. Therefore, the normal subgroups of A4A_4A4​ are {e},C2×C2,A4◃A4\{e\}, C_2 \times C_2, A_4 \triangleleft A_4{e},C2​×C2​,A4​◃A4​.

Theorem. A5A_5A5​ is simple.

Proof.

S5S_5S5​ has the following conjugacy classes:

Conjugacy classSize
{e}\{e\}{e}111
Single transpositions (e.g. (12)(12)(12))(52)5 \choose 2(25​) =10= 10=10
333-cycles (e.g. (123)(123)(123))151515
444-cycles (e.g. (1234)(1234)(1234))303030
555-cycles (e.g. (12345)(12345)(12345))242424
Double transpositions (e.g. (12)(34)(12)(34)(12)(34))(52)5 \choose 2(25​) (32)3 \choose 2(23​) =15=15=15

Of these conjugacy classes, {e}\{e\}{e}, 333-cycles, 555-cycles and double transpositions are in A5A_5A5​; double transpositions are not split, 555-cycles are split (as they are centralized by a group of order 555, which must be the cyclic group of 555-cycles, which are even), and 333-cycles are not split because (12)(12)(12), which is odd, centralizes (345)(345)(345). This leads to the following conjugacy classes for A5A_5A5​:

Conjugacy classSize
{e}\{e\}{e}111
333-cycles (e.g. (123)(123)(123))151515
555-cycles, class 111121212
555-cycles, class 222121212
Double transpositions (e.g. (12)(34)(12)(34)(12)(34))(52)5 \choose 2(25​) (32)3 \choose 2(23​) =15=15=15

If GGG is a normal subgroup of A5A_5A5​, then by Lagrange's Theorem ∣G∣|G|∣G∣ must divide 5!/2=605!/2=605!/2=60; moreover we see from the size of the conjugacy classes that, excepting the identity subgroup {e}\{e\}{e}, the minimal size of a normal subgroup (formed from the union of conjugacy classes) is 12+1=1312 + 1 = 1312+1=13. The possible values for the order of GGG are thus all the divisors of 606060 greater than 131313: 15,3015, 3015,30 and 606060. None of these can be formed from the sums of the orders of the above conjugacy classes excepting 606060, which is the union of all of them at once; thus, the only normal subgroups of A5A_5A5​ is {e}\{e\}{e} and itself, and so A5A_5A5​ is simple. □\square□
